block.p: President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia sought the endorsement of also-rans in Sunday's voting and began maneuvering to move up the date of a runoff election. A1
Communist leaders say their support stagnated in recent months because Mr. Yeltsin shut them out of the media and ran an exhaustively negative campaign. A1
A Russian power broker recast himself as a moderate. A10
China pledged to crack down more effectively on the piracy of intellectual property like computer programs and compact disks, forestalling American trade sanctions. A1
Agreements signed by Benjamin Netanyahu have spelled out the price exacted by Orthodox Jewish parties for their support of the incoming Israeli government. A3
The Israeli Parliament is sworn in, but without a new government. A3
The Defense Department said it had "no conclusive proof that Americans are being held against their will" in North Korea. A6
Germany's dissidents have joined an old battle. A12
British officials hardened stand on talks with I.R.A. allies. A13
Sarajevo Journal: Ex-neighbors remember Radovan. A4

The Federal Aviation Administration shut down Valujet indefinitely after finding what it termed "serious deficiencies" during its evaluation of the company after the May 11 crash in the Everglades. A1
WHITE HOUSE AIDE PUT ON LEAVE
The White House announced it was placing on administrative leave the head of the office that collected the confidential F.B.I. files. A1 TESTING ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE
Special Report: the Federal Office of Alternative Medicine, in its five years of existence, has yet to show that any alternative therapy works or does not work. A1
Bob Dole said he was trying to heal the rifts on abortion within the Republican Party. A18
Senator Frank H. Murkowski of Alaska introduced a bill to issue a highly unusual long-term timber contract that could help shore up a bank in which the Senator holds stock. A14
Vice President Al Gore was on the attack, criticizing a Dole press aide who he said distorted his words on the link between smoking and lung cancer. A18
Investigators are looking into fires at two more Southern churches, one black and one white. A16
Guggenheim Museum SoHo surfs into the video era. C15
Broadcasters preparing for new ruling on children's TV. C15
New editor for The New Republic. C18

Dance: The Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane troupe. C15
Books: "Why Things Bite Back," by Edward Tenner. C17
Basketball: Where do the Bulls go from here? B13
Gymnastics: Miller and Moceanu want to skip Olympic trials. B9
Football: Blades's manslaughter conviction is overturned. B15
Track and Field: Lewis gets through Olympic qualifying round. B9
Richard S. Lindzen views global warming skeptically. C1
Mating can be an evolutionary battle between the sexes. C1
The solar system is cruising toward a bumpy patch. C1
A new primate species has been found in the Amazon. C4
Personal Computers C5, C11 Fashion B8

Katha Pollitt: A dangerous game on abortion.
